speaker: Patient
text: I'm kinda embarrassed, but after two sprays this morning my nose stung and a tiny bit of pink came out when I blew it. I, uh, wonder if I'm doing it wrong. The pills still make me sleepy, so I want the spray to work.

speaker: Clinician
text: Thanks for telling me right away. The safety desk pinged me about mild bleeds, so let's double-check technique; angle and timing are usually the culprits, not anything dangerous.

speaker: Clinician
text: Picture a small triangle: tip of the nozzle points toward your ear, not the septum. One gentle sniff, hold breath, then exhale through mouth slowly.

speaker: Clinician
text: If dryness still hits, try squirting plain saline first and waiting a minute. That moistens tissue, reduces sting, and washes away pollen residue, uh, like prepping a windshield before wipers.

speaker: Clinician
text: Stick with one spray per nostril daily; more isn't better and costs extra. Loratadine remains one tablet each morning, ideally with coffee to cement the habit.

speaker: Patient
text: Okay, got it: ear angle, saline prep, one puff per side. I’ll, uh, stop doubling up on days I feel stuffed. If the bleeding comes back tomorrow, should I message or just walk in again?
